content.description: Crack in the obvious left facing corner. Starts as fingers and hands and widens to some flaring offwidth and then chimney. Crack goes for about 30 feet, then climb easy slab up to bolted anchor.
content.protection: Single rack. I don't think I placed anything bigger than a #1 C4.
content.location: Walk to the right after approaching the base of the crag and you will come to the left facing corner of Troll.

climbs.name: Pimping Pinksky
climbs.fa: Scott Lovell & Gareth Slattery 2014, FFA Ed Pinsky & Matt Hickey 2015

content.description: Short sport climb left of the obvious Elf Crack. Cracks/crimps to a few loose-feeling flakes up higher.
content.location: Far right end of LCL, 5 ft right of Elf Crack.

content.description: Another great, short crack climb. Climb up the obvious offwidth. Some nice feet on the face and a great jug make this not as much of a struggle as most 5.9 offwidths. The difficulties are over after about 25 feet and then finish up some easy rock and the slab to a fixed anchor (same anchor as for Elf Crack).
content.location: Walk right (uphill) along the base until you come to this beauty!

content.description: Dirty cracks to slab with 2 bolts. Current crux is lichen on the slab.
content.location: First route you come across on the slaby left side of LCL. Start on jugs left of tree in photo.

content.description: Climb the crack/flake in the shallow left facing corner. Starts as hand size and then gets thin for a few moves. Crack then widens out again and arches left, forming a nice little roof to pull at the end (at about 30 feet). Follow the large flake up easy slab to bolted anchor (same anchor as for Troll).
content.protection: Gear up to 2" will get it done. Bring some small cams and nuts for the thin section, I placed a c3 (red I think??) and a small nut.
content.location: Walk right from the approach to the crag, this will be one of the first steep cracks you come to. The little overhang at the top is an easy feature to look for.

content.description:
Starts as 4 inch crack and narrows as you climb. Pull up onto easy slab after 30 to 35 feet or so and climb up to fixed anchor (block slung with cord).

 Best route at this little crag, in my opinion (So good I climbed it twice!)
content.location: Furthest right crack at the crag. Walk up the hill along the base and you can't miss it.

content.description:
ACCESS-

 ACCESS NOTICE - The North side of Kinsman Notch was the scene of a forest fire during Oct 2017.

 Update 2019 -   Since the fire this entire area has seen extensive clean up and trail work by Jamie Cunningham and local climbers and most routes are climbable including all three pitches of Black Tourmaline.  The crags are all open now and expect to find lots of new growth ferns and small shrubs along the trail as nature takes care of the fire damage.  Jamie recommends folks bring in loppers (or hand clippers) and a small saw for any further trail and route maintenance. It also appears (to me) most bolts have been replaced...at least they all looked new to me on Lower Patina Wall in Sept 2019.

 A nice selection of cracks. About 7 routes from 5.6 to 5.12a, most 5.6 to 5.9

NOTE: Lose Blocks - As of 9/28/19 There are some very loose toaster oven/microwave sized loose stones to the left of the Troll/Gargoyle anchors. Take care not to dislodge them with your feet while belaying or rapping as It wouldn't take much to knock them loose on those at the cliff base.
